title: 2021 Locust Density Analysis
text:
This page presents the visualizations and statistical analyses conducted on the 2021 field survey dataset, supporting ongoing manuscript development for publication.
The analyses focus on Senegalese locust (OSE) density and ground cover data collected across multiple regions and fertilizer treatments in Senegalese agricultural fields. The goal of this page is to replicate the current figures in the manuscript. This is to ensure visuals are made in the same way but also to ensure that my data management aligns well with expectations and that there are no errors. If you see errors, please let me know!

title: 2021 Locust Density Analysis
text:
This page presents the visualizations and statistical analyses conducted on the 2021 field survey dataset, supporting ongoing manuscript development for publication.
The analyses focus on Senegalese locust (OSE) density and ground cover data collected across multiple regions and fertilizer treatments in Senegalese agricultural fields. The goal of this page is to replicate the current figures in the manuscript. This is to ensure visuals are made in the same way but also to ensure that my data management aligns well with expectations and that there are no errors. If you see errors, please let me know!

title: 2021 Locust Density Analysis
text:
Major questions:

OSE densiy plots: do you prefer option 1 or 2 (assuming that we could workshop either one to be better)?
OSE densiy x ground cover: I am unable to replicate the curves seen in the mansucript (figure 5), can you confirm how the data was handled in this analysis?
annual OSE density: my averages do not add up to the numbers reported in table 1 in the manuscript, can you confirm how the data was handled for this table?
For model summaries (e.g. p values) how would we like to handle them? Would you prefer in-line references or supplementary tables?

title: 2021 Locust Density Analysis
section: OSE density by treatment and region (option 1)
text:
OSE density by treatment and region (option 1)


Code
# A list of model results with emmeans
mission_emms <- bind_rows(
  lapply(names(mission_emmeans), function(nm) {
    # Add the list element name as a column:
    df <- mission_emmeans[[nm]]$emmeans
    df$source <- nm
    df
  }),
  .id = 'mission_numer' 
)

count_plot_option_1 <- plot_mission_density(
    data |> drop_na(ose_count,fertilizer_treatment),
    mission_emms,
    regions = c('Saint Louis','Thies','Fatick','Kaffrine'),
    legend_position = 'bottom'
) 

count_plot_option_1

title: 2021 Locust Density Analysis
section: OSE density by treatment and region (option 2)
text:
OSE density by treatment and region (option 2)
Instead of a plot per mission, lets plot the missions together (x-axis) and see how region counts shifted through time


Code
count_plot_option_2 <- plot_emmeans(mission_emms,
    color_palette = "Degas",
    ylab = "OSE count",
    xlab = "Mission")

count_plot_option_2

title: 2021 Locust Density Analysis
section: OSE density by teatment and region model summaries (tabulated)
text:
OSE density by teatment and region model summaries (tabulated)
Here are the model summaries and pairwise comparisons. This will be across missions, but please keep in mind each mission had it’s own model. So we cant make across-mission comparions just yet.


Code
library(broom.mixed)
mission_mod_summary <- bind_rows(
  lapply(names(mission_mods), function(nm) {
    # Add the list element name as a column:
    df <- mission_mods[[nm]] |> tidy()
    df$source <- nm
    df
  }),
  .id = 'mission_number' 
)

mission_emms <- bind_rows(
  lapply(names(mission_emmeans), function(nm) {
    # Add the list element name as a column:
    df <- mission_emmeans[[nm]]$emmeans
    df$source <- nm
    df
  }),
  .id = 'mission_number' 
)

mission_pairs <- bind_rows(
  lapply(names(mission_emmeans), function(nm) {
    # Add the list element name as a column:
    df <- mission_emmeans[[nm]]$pairwise
    df$source <- nm
    df
  }),
  .id = 'mission_number' 
)

library(gt)
library(dplyr)


mission_mod_summary <- mission_mod_summary |>
  arrange(mission_number) |>
  mutate(effect = ifelse(effect == 'ran_pars', 'random', 'fixed'),
    term = ifelse(term == 'sd__(Intercept)','farmer',term),
    term = gsub('fertilizer_treatment|region','',term)) |>
  select(!c(component,group))



mission_mod_summary |>
  select(!source) |>
  gt(groupname_col = "mission_number") |>
  fmt_number(
    columns = c(estimate, std.error, statistic, p.value),
    decimals = 3
  ) |>
  cols_label(
    mission_number = "Mission",
    effect = "Effect",
    term = "Term",
    estimate = "Estimate",
    std.error = "Std. Error",
    statistic = "Statistic",
    p.value = "P-value"
  ) |>
  tab_header(
    title = "OSE density by treatment and region by mission"
  ) |>
  as_raw_html()

Here are the pairwise comparisons between region and treatment by mission number. Fair warning, its a large table since there are a lot of regions.


Code
mission_pairs |>
  arrange(contrast) |>
  select(!source) |>
  gt(groupname_col = "mission_number") |>
  fmt_number(
    columns = c(ratio, SE, z.ratio, p.value),
    decimals = 3
  ) |>
  tab_header(
    title = "OSE density model pairwise comparisons by mission"
  ) |>
  as_raw_html()

title: 2021 Locust Density Analysis
text:
GAM model summary


Code
broom.mixed::tidy(plant_cover_mod) |>
  gt() |>
  fmt_number(
    columns = c(edf, ref.df, statistic, p.value),
    decimals = 2
  ) |>
  cols_label(
    term = "Term",
    edf = "Estimated DF",
    ref.df = "Reference DF",
    statistic = "F Statistic",
    p.value = "P-value"
  ) |>
  tab_header(
    title = "GAM model Summary: OSE Density x Plant Cover"
  ) |>
  tab_options(
    table.font.size = "small",
    row.striping.background_color = "#F6F6EF"
  ) |>
  as_raw_html()

title: Fertilization Effects on Oedaleus senegalensis and Millet Yield in Senegal
text:
This site presents a reproducible analysis of the 2021 Oedaleus senegalensis (OSE) dataset, collected by Mamour and collaborators across four regions of Senegal: Fatick, Kaffrine, Thiès, and Saint-Louis. The study examined how fertilizer application influences grasshopper densities and millet yield, while also providing insights into OSE’s regional dynamics and distribution along a rainfall gradient.
The analyses and figures here build on previous work from our Scientific Reports paper, applying similar statistical frameworks to an expanded dataset that includes additional regions and survey rounds. All scripts, data processing, and visualizations are documented in this Quarto project for transparency and reproducibility.

title: Fertilization Effects on Oedaleus senegalensis and Millet Yield in Senegal
text:
This site presents a reproducible analysis of the 2021 Oedaleus senegalensis (OSE) dataset, collected by Mamour and collaborators across four regions of Senegal: Fatick, Kaffrine, Thiès, and Saint-Louis. The study examined how fertilizer application influences grasshopper densities and millet yield, while also providing insights into OSE’s regional dynamics and distribution along a rainfall gradient.
The analyses and figures here build on previous work from our Scientific Reports paper, applying similar statistical frameworks to an expanded dataset that includes additional regions and survey rounds. All scripts, data processing, and visualizations are documented in this Quarto project for transparency and reproducibility.

title: Fertilization Effects on Oedaleus senegalensis and Millet Yield in Senegal
text:
Study Background
During the 2021 growing season (July–October), 250 farmers participated in a paired-field experiment where each managed: - One fertilized field receiving 150 kg each of NPK and urea. - One non-fertilized control field.
Each field was surveyed three times to record: - Grasshopper density and developmental stage
- Vegetation cover and temperature
- Millet yield at harvest
In total, the survey covered 500 ha across 1,500 sampling points. The Saint-Louis region, which experienced extreme dryness that year, was only sampled twice due to field abandonment.

title: Fertilization Effects on Oedaleus senegalensis and Millet Yield in Senegal
text:
Analytical Goals
We are exploring several complementary objectives:

Fertilization and Pest Pressure:
Quantify how fertilizer affects OSE density using mixed-effects models, assessing whether improved plant vigor corresponds to lower infestation rates and look how OSE density is influenced by ground cover
OSE density impacts on millet yield (page TBA)
understand how millet yield is influence by OSE presence (and presumabley millet damage)
Regional Dynamics and Rainfall Gradients (page TBA)
Evaluate OSE abundance in relation to mean annual rainfall and latitude, to infer how climatic gradients structure its range across Senegal.
Generational and Temporal Patterns (page TBA)
Visualize the timing of OSE developmental stages across regions to assess whether northern populations are locally derived or the result of seasonal migrations.

title: Fertilization Effects on Oedaleus senegalensis and Millet Yield in Senegal
text:
Visual and Analytical Outputs
All figures are reproducible from R scripts stored in the R/ folder and rendered through this Quarto project.

title: Fertilization Effects on Oedaleus senegalensis and Millet Yield in Senegal
text:
Citation and Acknowledgments
This analysis was prepared by Douglas Lawton and collaborators. The work contributes to our understanding of pest dynamics and millet production systems in the Sahel and supports the forthcoming manuscript submission to the Journal of Economic Entomology.
For full reproducibility, see the GitHub repository or cite the Zenodo archive:
DOI: 10.5281/zenodo.xxxxxx
